module.keywords: module, systems engineering, system behavior, system structure, trade study, program management, project management, risk management, issue management, decision support, analysis

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of the variety of general model classifications used to support model based systems engineering. This includes all models used to characterize the physical structure and its behavior and the full range of models used to support system engineering trade studies.

This module is the top level application module for AP233. It brings together the system modelling capabilities and the program management capabilities. As such, the variety of modeling paradigms used to represent the physical and functional system and capabilites used to support associated verification, validation and trade studies as well as the program managment activities of systems engineering.

usage_guide.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of systems engineering.

This part of ISO 10303 uses the set of application modules for product data management information (the "PDM Modules"). These are based on the "PDM Schema" that was developed to achieve harmonization between application protocols ISO 10303-203, ISO 10303-214 and ISO 10303-232.
This part of ISO 10303 has its conceptual base founded in "Concept model" that can be downloaded at . and its companion semantic dictionary can be downloaded at .

These two interwoven documents have been extensively reviewed by the ISO AP233 development team, members of the International Council on Systems Engineering (INCOSE) and members of the Object Managemement Groups (OMG). The work was performed via the the leadership efforts of INCOSE's Model Driven Design working group . This group has, in its efforts to extend best practices of System Engineering into softwere engineeering succeed in initiating the SysML project within the OMG and assisting with that activity. The home page for the SysML partners is . The memo of uncderstanding between the 2 groups (INCOSE and OMG) can be downloaded at: .

In mid 2005 AP233 Working draft 1 (AP233-WD1) was delivered. Basically is captured all that was needed for AP233 from the perspective of a systems engineer. Since delivery the STEP/EXPRESS modeling expert arm of the AP233 team has been enhancing and restructuring AP233 WD1. The net result is the current product that is much better from the perspective of "information modelling"; however, much more difficult to penetrate from the perspective of a systems engineer.
The following few paragraphs attempt to bridge the gap by tracing ap233's evolution and maing appropriate connects to current AP233 modules used.

ul.li: The information model is now partitioned into a program management arm and a system modelling arm.
In AP233 WD1 "system of systems" is identified. This is now all covered within the "System structure arm".
In AP233 WD1 many boxes are labeled "connector". The function that these boxes enabled is now hidden but enabled via the EXPRESS model Extensible SELECT TYPE capability.

Figure 2 attempts to show system engineering information modelling connectivity steming from the systems engineer's need to satisfy requirements and enable interfaces. Much of this work is also hidden but enabled via the EXPRESS model Extensible SELECT TYPE capability.

usage_guide.p: The subject domains of validation, verification, test and measurement are covered in the concept model. Included within this work is the subject of "issues". A number of early attempts to define and bound this module have been made. The collected notes on this subject can be downloaded at .

The inital ideas for the system of systems work noted in AP233 WD1 and enabled herein can be found in Chapter 15 of David Oliver's book "Engineering Complex Systems with Models and Objects". This can be freely downloaded at .

The AP233 WD1 team has most assuredly missed concepts within its Concept model and all that has been inferred from it. Fortunately documents that reflect a generation of experience supporting real world projects exists. The following work has been used to guide various aspects of current work.
The first is Vitech Corp's. schema for their CORE software product. This can be downloaded at . This schema has grown through a generation of system engineering customer support.
The second is the Department of Defense (US) Architectural framework (DoDAF). The following DoD reference source material can be downloaded as a single zip file from:

ol.li: The DoD Architecture Framework (DoDAF) Version 1.0 (.pdf) Memorandum by John P. Stenbit, February 9, 2004. The DoDAF Version 1.0 defines a common approach for DoD architecture description, development, presentation, and integration for both warfighting operations and business processes. The DoDAF Version 1.0 supersedes the C4ISR Architecture Framework, Version 2.0 dated December 18, 1997. The DoDAF Version 1.0 is partitioned into two volumes and a deskbook - see links provided directly below:
DoDAF Version 1.0 - Volume I (.pdf) Provides definitions, guidelines, background material.
DoDAF Version 1.0 - Volume II (.pdf) Describes each architecture product.
DoDAF Version 1.0 - Deskbook (.pdf) Provides supplementary "how to" information relating to architectures.

At the ISO SC4 STEP meeting in Hanzhou China Oct 2005 there was an detail review of AP233 WD1. This work, with minimal modification, has laid the foundationn for all that is included herein. These notes follow:

p.b: Begin - Notes from SC4 Meeting in Hangzhou and post meeting email exchanges

usage_guide.p: Re. Top level organization - The top level organization of AP233 needs to be changed to become more consistent with good information modeling practice. The vision is to have 2 second tier modules namely:

ol.li: USE FROM Project_management_arm;
USE FROM System_modelling_arm;

usage_guide.p: Both of these 2 send tier modules make use of the set set of common product data management capabilities as provided in setpmod; namely:

ol.li: USE FROM Product_data_management_arm;

usage_guide.p: The Project_management_arm will support all system engineering management activities and the System_modelling_arm; will cover all system modeling and engineering activities.
Re. Breakdown organization - The underlying logic controlling schema breakdown will be based upon Implementation Modules (IM's)
The Project_management_arm module will contain the USE FROM's that support

ol.li: Product data management
PDM Extra stuff (e.g., justification, information rights, etc.)
Schedule and work (with cost included) as a single Implementation Module (IM)
Issue management
Risk management

usage_guide.p: The System_modelling_arm module will contain the USE FROM's that support

ol.li: System behavior (Function + State based behavior)
System structure (Breakdown + Interface)
Requirements management (Text + Property based)
Trade study
Verification and validation, etc.

usage_guide.p: Re. Type Extends - The series of connector modules xxxx_connector identified in WD#1 will change. Associated detail is is work in progress. The underlying plcs logic will be followed so as to maximize reuse. We need to make use of work_xxxx_characterized modules. These will require use of ap239_management_resource_information and ap239_properties. Signficant type extending exists in AP239 in the IM modules AP239_xxxx. These cannot be used directly; however they provide some guidance on type extending.

Re. Reference data - Detail is still to be determined. Guidance - Reference data standardized in AP233 must be identified in a Conformance Clause within the AP document. A way forward has been outlined. From a user perspective: Any organization is free to categorize as then need. Reference data can be used to provide associated definitions.
